title: 115_hr3077
content: The "Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act of 2017" repeals the Retirement Earnings Test. The "Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act of 2017" repeals various subsections of the Social Security Act and makes conforming amendments to section 203. The "Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act of 2017" makes amendments to the Social Security Act, including changes to subsections and provisions related to benefits and exemptions. Amendments to the Social Security Act include changes to sections 202(s), 202(t)(7), and exemptions from reductions in benefits. Amendments to the Social Security Act involve changes to various subsections, including adjustments to benefit reductions and penalties for misrepresentations regarding earnings. Amendments to the Social Security Act include changes to benefit computation years, rounding of benefits, and defining income for purposes of SSI. These changes involve adjustments to earnings descriptions and wage definitions. The term 'wages' for Social Security Act purposes is defined without certain limitations on remuneration amounts. It includes specific services performed within or outside the United States and excludes certain types of payments made to employees or their dependents. The text discusses the repeal of deductions on account of work under the Railroad Retirement Program, specifically amending sections of the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974. It addresses changes in subsections and conforming amendments related to reductions in payments upon retirement. Section 4(g)(2) of the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974 is amended to remove deductions related to work under the program. These amendments will apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2018.
